hedline.hl1: Monaco's Top 5 Sales (and a Rusty Maserati)

abstract.p: Photos of highest-priced collectible cars sold at lavish auction in Monte Carlo; 1963 Ferrari SWB 250 GT California Spyder sells for $1,023,799

block.p: MONTE CARLO is accustomed to rich and beautiful people. In late May, it was a backdrop for rich and beautiful cars, too, as three auction companies held events on the same weekend.

Not since 1990, when the collector-car market was at a frenzied peak, have there been three consecutive auctions in Monaco. Brooks Europe, which was conducting its 10th annual Monaco auction, was joined by Barrett-Jackson, an American auction company, and Poulain Le Fur, a French auction house. It was Barrett-Jackson's first event outside its home base in Scottsdale, Ariz.; it teamed up with Coys of Kensington, based in London, to take advantage of the dollar's strength against European currencies (and American collectors' appetite for high-end European cars).
MONTE CARLO is accustomed to rich and beautiful people. In late May, it was a backdrop for rich and beautiful cars, too, as three auction companies held events on the same weekend.

Not since 1990, when the collector-car market was at a frenzied peak, have there been three consecutive auctions in Monaco. Brooks Europe, which was conducting its 10th annual Monaco auction, was joined by Barrett-Jackson, an American auction company, and Poulain Le Fur, a French auction house. It was Barrett-Jackson's first event outside its home base in Scottsdale, Ariz.; it teamed up with Coys of Kensington, based in London, to take advantage of the dollar's strength against European currencies (and American collectors' appetite for high-end European cars).

The lavish Barrett/Coys event brought in $5.6 million, including buyers' premiums, with 30 cars sold of the 50 offered. Craig Jackson, owner of Barrett-Jackson, said, ''We brought the American bidders, and Coys brought the European merchandise.''

Brooks Europe, with the most variety, sold 46 of the 72 cars offered for a total of $6.2 million. By presenting cars new to the market, Brooks got top-end prices. Poulain Le Fur, in partnership with Sotheby's, put on a smaller sale, bringing in $3.8 million.
At all three auctions, rare Ferraris, especially those with racing histories, brought the highest bids.
1963 Ferrari SWB 250 GT California Spyder $1,023,799 (Poulain Le Fur/Sotheby's)

The 52nd of 54 such cars built, this one's history is known from the day it left the factory. Black, with a red leather interior, it is in excellent condition. The only car of its type on the market today, it could easily have brought another $100,000 without surprising the experts.
In the United States since 1963 and fully restored in 1988, this supercharged Mercedes has won many concours prizes and has been driven fewer than 40,000 miles since new.
This alloy-body SWB was fully restored but fitted with a replacement engine. With the original, it could have been worth another $200,000.
1956 Ferrari 250 GT ''Tour de France'' Competizione Berlinetta $752,954 (Brooks Europe)
An early-production TdF, it had been out of the market for 32 years, sitting in a Danish museum. It will require a total restoration but has the potential to be a distinctive prize-winning show car.
1965 Ferrari 275 GTB Speciale Competizione Berlinetta $831,165 (Brooks Europe)

The price of this car, in nightmarish condition after 33 years in storage in Egypt -- it was seized after its owner, the exiled King Saud of Saudi Arabia, left the country -- was the surprise of the weekend. One of 32 built -- just one of two with a body by Frua, an Italian coachbuilder -- the car has been driven only 2,100 miles.
